Constructor Detail

GuiWidget

public GuiWidget()
Subclasses that implement widgets with several options should not call this constructor. Although subclasses can call super(widgetID), this should be avoided because it would mean calling the addWidget twice on the InteractionManager.

Parameters:
widgetID - The id of this widget (must be unique within the application).
suggestedReferenceCode - The suggested reference code
Method Detail

setWidget

public void setWidget(Widget widget)
Sets the widget associated with this GuiWidget.

Parameters:
widget -

onInput

public final void onInput(java.util.ArrayList<InputEvent> inputList)
Event triggered by the InteractionManager to signal input to this widget. This method calls the fireActionEvent method with a default ActionEvent. Subclasses should override to generate specific ActionEvents and fire them using fireActionEvent()

Specified by:
onInput in interface InputListener
Parameters:
ie - An InputEvent object.

handleInput

public InputFeedback<GuiWidget> handleInput(InputEvent ie)

inputFeedbackStarted

public void inputFeedbackStarted(InputFeedback<? extends GuiWidget> feedback)
Triggers the processing of the specified InputFeedback.

Specified by:
inputFeedbackStarted in interface InputFeedbackListener
Parameters:
feedback - The feedback to process.

inputFeedbackEnded

public void inputFeedbackEnded(InputFeedback<? extends GuiWidget> feedback,
                               boolean noMore)
Stops the processing of the specified feedback. This method will always be called with the same InputFeedback that the previous start method and will always be interleaved with start calls.

Specified by:
inputFeedbackEnded in interface InputFeedbackListener
Parameters:
feedback - The feedback to stop showing.

fireActionEvent

protected void fireActionEvent(ActionEvent<? extends GuiWidget> ae)
Fires an ActionEvent to all registered listeners of this Widget. Subclasses should always call this method to fire ActionEvents since this method does the necessary checking of whether this widget is input enabled or not. This method also implements the auto-disable feature.

Parameters:
ae - The ActionEvent to fire. If null, a default ActionEvent will be created and sent.

setInputEnabled

public void setInputEnabled(boolean inputEnabled)
Enables or disables this Widget's processing of InputEvents. If disabled, the Widget will no longer fire ActionEvents. Subclasses should obey this rule and call fireActionEvent (which does this checking) to fire ActionEvents to their listeners.

Parameters:
inputEnabled -

isInputEnabled

public boolean isInputEnabled()

setEnabled

public void setEnabled(boolean enabled)
Sets the visual feedback of the widget to enabled or disabled. This settings affects only the visual state. The widget may still receive input even if its visual state indicates otherwise.

Parameters:
enabled -

getWidgetId

public java.lang.String getWidgetId()
Returns this widget's id. There is no setId() because the id of a widget cannot be changed after it is set in the constructor.

Returns:
This widget's WidgetID.
See Also:
